Apr 12

Timesheets: the Good, the Bad and the Necessary

Timesheets: most people hate them. At the same time, many companies consider them necessary for managing their projects.

Charles Chu, writer and traveler, has pointed out in his article on Medium, Peter Drucker: How to (Actually) Manage Your Time, that every successful company, manager or a worker starts with one thing:

Execution.

He explained it with the “Drucker Method” — originally described by Peter Drucker, the guru of project management, a prolific writer who has written over 30 books on the topic.

And the key point of this method is:

You need to master your time.

To do so, the #1 thing is to start recording it. Because, as Drucker said, humans tend to forget how their time has been spent.

And it’s not only him who realized it:

According to the Ebbinghaus Forgetting Curve, humans only retain 23 percent of what they learn after six days.

This fact translates into the lack of accuracy in timesheets filled after more than a day, as people forget what they did and how much time it took them.

Only after you record your time, you can analyze how you had spent it, and optimize the future tasks.

So if you want to better manage the assignments you or your employees are working on, you need to track the time dedicated to it.

And timesheets are one of the most common ways to do so.

The problem is:

How to make the most out of them, considering the pros and cons of using them?

To better understand how you can effectively use timesheets in your organisation, let’s start with outlining timesheets’ pitfalls and benefits.

The perils of using timesheets

First off, you need to remember that timesheets may be misleading. There are various reasons for that, and not filling timesheets consistently is one of them.

People forget to fill in their timesheets

Not filling in timesheets everyday, for example, is one of the reasons why they are inaccurate, according to Accelo study:

It’s impossible to be completely accurate with your timesheet if you’re only completing it once a week.

Another thing is that people tend to not fill in everything they do.

The same study has shown that not including emails or meetings in the daily timesheets, can be simply translated into the potential money loses for the company:

  • Writing and answering emails causes professionals to leak over $50,000 in revenue per year
  • Meetings and calls cause professionals to leak over $32,000 in revenue per year
  • Moving from weekly timesheet updates to daily would recover $52,000 per professional, per year in billable time.

Time is not the only metric

The third thing you need to know is that timesheets won’t tell you about the effectiveness of your projects, Tim Williams says:

The reality is timesheets tell you almost nothing about the measurements that really matter in knowledge work

In his Linkedin post What Timesheets Don’t Tell You he argues that it’s not the best way to measure the success of your project, client satisfaction, or the overall quality of the work completed.

Last but not least, people hate timesheets, as Matthew Stibbe put it in his article Why timesheets are evil. And he’s right. Let’s be honest about it.

The benefits of using timesheets

At the other hand, there are still a lot of advantages of implementing timesheets in your company.

See where the money comes from

If you run a company that bills by the hour, you may use timesheets to better evaluate where the majority of your income comes from.

For example, if you have several projects, you can compare how much money you got from them vs how much time it took you or your employees to finish the tasks.

Maybe you have this one project which takes you way too much time, but it doesn’t adequately contribute to the company’s profits. Or there is a client that pays you well, but requires extra resources to finish project.

Proper time tracking and reliable timesheets will help you to recognize these issues and allocate your employees accordingly.

Better evaluate future projects

51% of the projects weren’t completed on time, while 47% didn’t meet the original budget, according to PMI research.

Both of these issues can be solved by properly filled timesheets and accurate time reports.

Why? Because evaluating finished tasks and projects gives you an ability to diagnose, consolidate, and optimize the time spent on a given project — exactly as Drucker put it in his method.

Knowing how much time your employees needed to deliver some recent projects, you can better estimate the timeline and budget of the future ones.

And the #1 solution for more accurate timesheets is consistency:

People who log their time at least once a day are 66 percent accurate.

Better allocate your employees

Using timesheets can give you a glance at your employees’ current status in the projects, see when they are free or if they are being overwhelmed with different assignments.

Better resource allocation leads to more effective work, avoiding downtimes and employee underutilization or overworking.

How to make timesheets reliable

As you can see, the main disadvantages of using timesheets are based on human nature. It’s not timesheets that are wrong, it’s how we fill them in.

There are several tools,which try to tackle this problem. One of the solutions is automation.

What you could do is implementing a tool that works as a one-click timesheet. You click “play” when you start working on a given project or task and hit “stop” when you’re done.

Such timesheets are obviously very precise but also they’re filled out automatically, which makes things a lot easier for your team.

The idea is simple — if we’re too lazy or if we forget to fill in the timesheets, maybe the tool that will simplify it for us can solve the problem.

Granted, there are people who still would rather enter their time manually (because they tend to forget about the timer), so you can use software that is more flexible (teamdeck is an example of such an automatic/manual tool with extra resource management features).

On the other hand, many companies still don’t use a uniform internal system for reporting time, which makes it harder to allocate resources, especially while working with remote team members or part-timers.

Don’t forget that, when implementing time tracking as a new process in your team, you need to explain why everyone should track their time.

Using timesheets won’t tell you about your company’s effectiveness or the quality of work.

Instead, it will give you a bigger picture of how your employees work, and how to allocate them in projects for better results.

What do you think about the timesheets? Feel free to express yourself in the comments.
